newNodes.label: Data-driven analysis of COVID-19 social impacts
newNodes.description:
To conduct a data-driven analysis focusing on the social impacts of COVID-19 during and after the pandemic. Areas of initial interest:
1. The differential impact of COVID-19 and related policies on men versus women.
2. The translation of COVID-19 mitigation policies into social and economic effects, especially post-pandemic, possibly with a country-level breakdown.

newNodes.label: Effect of COVID-19 and mitigation policies on men vs women
newNodes.description: How did COVID-19 (the disease and mitigation policies) affect men versus women?

newNodes.label: Did COVID-19 mitigation policies translate into rise of political populism? If so, through what mechanisms?
newNodes.description: Did COVID-19 mitigation policies cause (or accelerate) a rise in political populism? If yes, via what mechanisms? Approach envisaged: comparative cross-country/cross-policy analysis with the best available datasets supporting such research.

versions.label: Post-pandemic outcomes of COVID-19 mitigation policies
versions.description: How did COVID-19 mitigation policies produce various social, economic, and political effects after the pandemic? Example outcomes of interest include: increased working from home, high inflation, rise of populism/extremism; open to additional effects. Focus is on identifying datasets that support analysis of such outcomes, with a preference for easily downloadable (CSV/TSV/JSON), easy-to-process sources (Kaggle and similar portals).

newNodes.label: Open datasets: gendered and policy impact of COVID-19
newNodes.description:
Curated list of open datasets useful for analyzing gendered impacts and policy-driven social/economic outcomes of COVID-19:

1. Gender-disaggregated health & social data:
  - Global Health 50/50 Sex-and-Gender COVID-19 Project
  - UN Women COVID-19 & Gender Data Hub
  - Data2X Gender & COVID19 Resources
  - World Bank Gender Data Portal (COVID-19)
  - European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE) COVID-19 Thematic Index
  - IHME COVID-19 Gender Equality Impact Estimates

2. Policy tracking, social & economic indicators:
  - Oxford COVID-19 Government Response Tracker (OxCGRT)
  - Protective Policy Index (PPI)
  - Nature’s COVID AMP Dataset
  - COVID-19 Policy Tracker Aggregator
  - World Bank / IMF COVID-19 Economic Impact Open Data

3. Supplementary social media & research corpora:
  - TBCOV: 2 billion tweets with gender/sentiment labels
  - Tweet datasets focusing on gendered differences
  - CORD-19 bibliographic corpora for text mining

4. Cross-sectional gender-social indices:
  - OECD Gender, Institutions & Development Database (GIDDB)
  - European Data Portal / Data.gov.uk / UK Data Service (COVID-era surveys)

newNodes.label: Suggested analytical steps for gendered and policy impact analysis
newNodes.description:
System suggestions to proceed:
- Pick scope & hypothesis (e.g., GH5050 + OxCGRT/PPI for gendered health outcomes; UN/World Bank survey + macroeconomic trends for long-term socioeconomic effect)
- Choose countries/regions based on data coverage (EU, lower-income via WB, global datasets)
- Time framing (align OxCGRT monthly indices, IHME estimates, Bank surveys 2020–22)
- Data cleaning/merging (harmonize country/time, lag structure ~6-12 months post-policy)
- Add qualitative/sentiment context (TBCOV, tweet analysis for gendered reaction)

summary: Goal and Research Questions were initiated: analyzing COVID-19’s social impacts with a gender and policy focus. Data node identified a curated list of relevant open datasets (gender-disaggregated, policy, economic, social media), mapped to both research questions. A Suggestion node captures recommended analytical steps, which also link to both research questions. All elements are now connected to the overall goal.

newNodes.label: Downloadable datasets: post-pandemic social, economic, and political effects

Targeted, easily downloadable datasets in CSV/TSV/JSON for analysis of post-pandemic effects of COVID mitigation policies:

1. Working from Home / Remote Work
  - Kaggle: Impact of COVID19 on Working Professionals (CSV)
  - Canada Open Data: Telework statistics (CSV)

2. Inflation & Economic Trends
  - World Bank Global Inflation Database (CSV)

3. Populism / Extremism & Political Effects

4. Policy & Case Data
  - Our World in Data COVID-19 dataset (policy, cases; CSV/JSON)

5. Social & Sentiment Data

All datasets are readily downloadable and suitable for merging/processing in Python, R, etc.

newNodes.label: Suggested data processing and analysis workflow (post-pandemic effects)
newNodes.description:
System's step-by-step suggestions:
- Map policy timeline to outcomes (use OurWorldInData / Google for policy & COVID stats)
- Overlay with socioeconomic data (inflation, GDP, remote work)
- Add public sentiment & politics (tweets, protest/Populism datasets)
- Data format readiness: All sources available in CSV/JSON with time/country keys. Surveys often have dictionaries and timestamps for ease of use in analytical environments.

newNodes.label: Datasets: Comparative study of mitigation policies and political populism
newNodes.description:
1. COVID-19 Mitigation Policies:
  - OxCGRT: Daily indicators (stringency, containment, economic) by country; CSV/JSON.
  - WNTRAC: >6,000 NPIs across 261 countries; CSV/TSV.

2. Measures of Populism:
  - Global Populism Database (Harvard): Populist rhetoric/discourse, country/period; CSV.
  - Votes for Populists (Stanford): Vote-shares for populist parties (Europe, LatAm, Asia) to 2023; CSV.
  - The PopuList: Expert-coded list of populist/far-left/right parties in Europe (1989–2022), vote-shares, metadata; OSF.

3. Democracy & Populist Behavior Metrics:
  - VDem: 500+ governance/polarization/democracy indicators; country-date CSV.

4. Political Events/Protests/Sentiment:
  - GDELT: Global protest/event/sentiment data, daily CAMEO-coded; downloadable CSV.
  - Wikipedia: ~50,000 anti-COVID protest events (2020–22); curated event list.

5. Mechanism-related contextual sources:
  - Scientific case studies: E.g., "medical populism," government blame-shifting, authoritarian overreach; for qualitative mechanism support.

newNodes.label: Comparative cross-country analysis workflow for policy-populism question
newNodes.description:
Step-by-step analytical workflow suggestion:
- Build panel (country × time: month/quarter)
- Per unit: compute avg. stringency (OxCGRT), NPI counts (WNTRAC), democracy metrics (V-Dem), populist outcomes (vote share/rhetoric), protest frequency (GDELT/Wikipedia)
- Model populist outcomes (vote share, rhetoric, protest spikes) as function of lagged policy intensity, controlling for democracy baseline, GDP, etc.
- Integrate qualitative mechanism evidence using case study literature (blame-shifting, policy overreach, etc.)

summary: Research Question 2 is now laser-focused on the rise of political populism linked to COVID-19 mitigation policies, specifying a comparative approach and interest in causal mechanisms. A new Data node details top datasets (OxCGRT, WNTRAC, populism/vote share, democracy indices, protest/event data, mechanism case studies) for this analysis. A dedicated Suggestion node introduces a comparative panel analysis workflow. New links connect these to the updated research question.

newNodes.label: Key literature findings: COVID policies and populism
newNodes.description:
Synthesized findings from major studies, academic papers, and think-tank/policy reports on the relationship between COVID-19 pandemic policies and the rise/intensification of political populism. Organized as:

1. Lasco (2020): 'Medical populism' as a political strategy (minimizing risks, politicizing science, framing experts as elites, dramatizing governmental response), deepened public distrust and polarization.
2. Hedges & Lasco (2021): Populist leaders simplified/disputed COVID testing; spectacle and divisive narratives; reduced testing campaign buy-in.
3. Social Science & Medicine (2024): Populist rhetoric during health crises erodes trust in science and public health, fuels misinformation/resistance.
4. Uluşahin et al. (2024): Populist beliefs correlate with non-compliance with containment measures (via anti-elitist distrust).
5. Policy report ('Perilous Mix...'): Populist governments neglected expertise, overstated success, consolidated power, reduced accountability.
6. Right-wing populism & resistance (2022): RWP correlates with refusal re: vaccination, mitigation, based on social identity and trust.
7. Case study reports (Philippines, Brazil, US): Populist leadership used pandemic to legitimize crackdowns, shift blame, polarize society.

Key Mechanisms Identified:
- Politicization of science (expert advice framed as elitism/control)
- Simplification/spectacle (crisis reframed in populist binaries)
- Distrust/non-compliance
- Crisis as justification for democratic backsliding
- Policies as political identity markers

Further reading suggested (Gerbaudo 2021, Lasco & Persson 2022) and links to media coverage of populist pandemic responses.

summary: Finding node added summarizing major scientific and policy-report outputs investigating the connection between COVID mitigation policies and political populism. This node structures the evidence by study, synthesizes identified mechanisms (e.g., politicization of science, distrust, identity polarization), and is linked to the central research question.

updatedNodes.label: Detailed profiles: OxCGRT, The PopuList, VDem (with recency and suitability details)
updatedNodes.description:
Detailed profiles for three key datasets, with an updated focus on VDem’s recency and suitability:

1. Oxford COVID-19 Government Response Tracker (OxCGRT)
- Description: Daily-coded COVID-19 policies for ~180 countries since Jan 2020; main dataset for quantifying policy response.
- Format: CSV, daily updates.
- Download: GitHub/direct.
- Variables: Stringency/Economic/Containment indices; detailed flags.
- Use: Quantify policy severity/duration; lag indicators to predict populist support/unrest.

2. The PopuList (Populist Parties in Europe)
- Description: Expert-curated European party list with ideology/vote shares.
- Format: TSV/CSV.
- Use: Track changes in populist support; merge with policy/other datasets.

3. VDem (Varieties of Democracy)
- Recency: Version 15 (March 2025) covers data up to 2024 (annual frequency); version 14 covered up to 2023.
- Suitability: Fully supports pre-, during, and post-pandemic analyses (2018–2024 easily extractable). Includes >500 indicators (populism, democracy, media, polarization, etc). Country-year dataset; also some month-level country-date data in recent releases. Special project: Pandemic Backsliding (Mar 2020–Jun 2021).
- Use: Direct, balanced before/after-COVID comparison; filtering for 2018–2024 supported.

newNodes.label: VDem recency and pre/post COVID suitability
newNodes.description: VDem’s latest versions (v15 in March 2025, v14 in 2024) offer annual country-level coverage up to 2024 for 202 countries. Enables direct pre/during/post-pandemic comparison (2018–2024 ideal), with 500+ indicators (democracy, populism, polarization, media, etc). Data is well-suited for evaluating changes in the pandemic context. Special projects and higher-frequency country-date data (in v14+) are available. Download "CountryYear Full+Others" CSV and filter for years/indicators as needed for trend/regression/pre-post work.

summary: The Explanation node details VDem dataset recency and suitability for pre/post COVID analysis (coverage through 2024, annual/monthly data options, 500+ indicators). The Data node for dataset profiles has been updated to capture these points and clarify VDem’s utility for comparative trend analysis.

newNodes.label: Recency limitation of VDem and impact on post-COVID populism assessment
newNodes.description: VDem v15 covers up to 2024, providing only a single year post-pandemic. This is likely insufficient for robust assessment of long-term populism trends driven by COVID policy. Populist electoral shifts and sentiment responses often have multi-year lags tied to election cycles. Subnational elections, referenda, and higher-frequency protest/sentiment data (e.g., GDELT, protest datasets) may provide early proxies or indications, but evidence of enduring impact will likely require 2025–2026 data or future releases.

newNodes.label: Early trend analysis and interim proxy supplement for populism
newNodes.description:
- Use monthly VDem Country-Date v2pepopul (2020–2024) for early signals.
- Supplement with protest events (anti-lockdown, vaccine, via GDELT/Wikipedia) and sentiment data (GDELT) for 2022–24.
- Track subnational elections and referenda tied to COVID policies (as interim candidates for effect detection).
- Plan mid-term follow-up: revisit after 2024/2025 national elections for robust long-term assessment.
- Compare cases where some countries show reversal/decline of populism post-pandemic (VDem 2024 data) as natural controls.

summary: The Data node has been updated to emphasize VDem’s post-COVID recency limitation and the limited time window for robust populism trend analysis. A new Insight node highlights this recency shortcoming, and a Suggestion node lists alternative approaches—using monthly VDem, protest/sentiment data, subnational elections, and planning for mid-term reassessment. These nodes are interlinked for clarity.

newNodes.label: European Social Survey (ESS): COVID-19, populism modules, timeline/status update
newNodes.description:
ESS survey rounds and module timeline:

- Round 10: 2020–2022. Includes COVID-19 module (trust, conspiracy beliefs, pandemic experience). Conducted during pandemic; limited for post-pandemic populism analysis.
- Round 11: 2023–24, released June 2024. Early post-pandemic attitudes on trust, institutions, but not dedicated populism/technocracy module. Covers late 2023 through spring 2024.
- Round 12: Planned for late 2025–26. Will field direct populism/technocracy attitudes, but data only expected in 2026 or later.
- CRONOS: Online interim (2024).

Recommendation: Use Round 11 for currently available early post-pandemic attitude data; plan for integration of Round 12 data in future analysis pipeline.
Merge-ready with other cross-country datasets (OxCGRT, VDem, GDELT, etc.).

newNodes.label: ESS enables mediation analysis: Mechanisms linking COVID-19 policies to populist attitudes
newNodes.description:
ESS modules deliver rich mechanism and outcome variables:

- Mechanisms: Round 10 trust and conspiracy belief measures (2020–21) capture cognitive/motivational pathways possibly linking pandemic responses to support for populism.
- Outcomes: Round 12 directly measures populist and technocratic attitudes; can test if pandemic-era distrust/conspiracies predicted later populist support.
- Strength: Cross-country comparability, strong data quality, ready merging with policy stringency indices.
- Research design: Enables mediation model: Stringency → Trust/Conspiracies → Populist Attitudes.

newNodes.label: Suggested ESS-populism mediation analysis workflow
newNodes.description:
- Download ESS Round 10 (COVID-19 Module), Round 12 (Populism/Technocracy), CRONOS from ESS Data Portal.
- Create country-level aggregates: avg. conspiracy belief, trust, compliance (Round 10); populist/technocratic support (Round 12).
- Merge with country-level OxCGRT stringency data (2020–21).
- Analyze model: Stringency → Trust/Conspiracies → Populist Attitudes.
- Supplement with protest (GDELT) and electoral trend data for triangulation.

summary: Three nodes are added: a Data node for the European Social Survey (ESS), an Insight node on mediation-pathway potential (trust/conspiracies as mechanisms), and a Suggestion node outlining an analysis workflow linking COVID-19 policies, institutional trust, and populist attitudes via ESS rounds. All are linked to the research question and relevant earlier data elements.

newNodes.label: Practical timeline constraint: Core post-pandemic populism attitude data from ESS not available until 2026+
newNodes.description: Only Round 11 (2023–24) data is available for post-pandemic European attitudes (trust, institutions); Round 12 with direct populism/technocracy modules will be collected 2025–26 and released after 2026. Thus, any mediation/pathway models for COVID → populist attitudes must initially be built with core trust/attitude variables—direct populism outcomes await future data.

- Prepare pipeline/documentation so that when Round 12 (2026+) is released, direct populist attitude outcomes can be quickly merged and retested for pathways/mechanism effects.

newNodes.label: OxCGRT: structure and contents
newNodes.description:
OxCGRT_latest.csv includes:
- Daily time-series observations for all countries and many sub-national units (e.g., US states, UK nations).
- Columns: CountryName, CountryCode (ISO-3), RegionName (if any), Date (YYYYMMDD format), and policy indicators.
- Policy indicators use codes with prefixes (C, E, H), e.g., C1_School closing; most ordinal, some binary; occasional implementation flags (C1_Flag for national/local).
- Aggregate indices: StringencyIndex (containment policy), GovernmentResponseIndex (all measures), ContainmentHealthIndex, EconomicSupportIndex (income/debt support), all scaled 0–100.

newNodes.label: Initial OxCGRT exploration and analysis suggestions
newNodes.description:
1. Aggregate daily OxCGRT data to monthly or yearly for analysis (mean, max).
2. Visualize timelines for a sample of countries showing policy harshness/lockdown waves.
3. Merge OxCGRT policy data with VDem/Populism datasets by CountryCode and Date/Year.
4. Lag policy variables to test for delayed relationships with political outcomes.
5. Sub-national analysis potential for the U.S. and other federations using RegionName.
6. Optionally provide file sample/snippet for interactive guidance (plotting, selection, aggregation).

summary: Added Data node for OxCGRT structure and contents, detailing file columns, policy indicators, and aggregate indices. newNodes.label: V-Dem v15: full structure and main variable domains
newNodes.description:
V-Dem (Varieties of Democracy) dataset structure and content as per codebook and system summary:

1. Core Indices (composite, continuous 0–1, country-year):
   - Liberal Democracy Index (LDI)
   - Electoral Democracy Index (EDI)
   - Participatory Democracy Index
   - Deliberative Democracy Index
   - Egalitarian Democracy Index

2. Elections & Electoral Integrity:
   - Free/fair election ratings (v2elefree, v2eltype_*)
   - Election violence, democracy types (autocracy/democracy)

3. Rule of Law & Judiciary:
   - Judicial independence (v2jureview, v2jupurge)
   - Access to justice, executive/judicial interaction

4. Freedom of Expression & Media:
   - Freedom of speech/media/academic (v2mefreedom, internet filtering etc.)

5. Civil Society & Participation:
   - Levels of civil society activism/repression
   - Rights to association/assembly
   - Government engagement with CSOs

6. Equality & Inclusion:
   - Equal protection under the law
   - Distribution of power—gender, class, ethnicity
   - Discrimination measures

7. Executive Constraints & Corruption:
   - Legislative/judicial/media checks on the executive
   - Executive corruption, transparency, accountability (v2excrptps)

8. Autocracy & Repression:
   - Measures of autocracy, regime type, purges
   - Political harassment, civil liberties violations

9. Political Parties:
   - Party bans/repression
   - Opposition autonomy
   - Party-society linkages

10. Miscellaneous/Other:
   - Regime duration/transitions, constitutional/military/religious role

Coverage: ~450 indicators, annotated by label. Annual, country-level, 1900–present. Full variable list can be extracted if needed. COVID-19 special section noted in dataset (not detailed here but present).

newNodes.label: Immediate VDem variable selection and prep workflow

newNodes.label: PopuList 3.0: actual CSV structure, coding conventions, columns, and research uses
newNodes.description:
Each row: political party in Europe, from PopuList 3.0 CSV (uploaded actual data).

Key columns (from real CSV / codebook):
- party_name (native), party_name_english, party_name_short, country_name
- Classification Labels (binary, 0/1): populist, farright, farleft, eurosceptic
- start and end years per label, including with/without borderline status (e.g. populist_start, populist_endnobl)
- special year codes: 1900 = initial year of series (e.g. 1989 for start), 2100 = ongoing/until last year in data (e.g. 2022 for end)
- populist_bl (flag for borderline notation)
- in_parliament (1 = yes as of Dec 31, 2022)
- partyfacts_id, parlgov_id (dataset joining)

Example: Lega/AfD (populist from 2013–2022), Kukiz’15 (2015–2020), "Party X" (classified 1989–1995, coded 1900 to 1995)
- Years 1900/2100 facilitate time-range analysis and harmonized plotting

Research uses (supported by real columns & encodings):
1. Track number and timeline of populist/far-right/far-left parties via start/end.
2. Join with COVID/policy datasets (OxCGRT, outcomes, Eurosceptic sentiment, etc).
3. Subgroup analysis and panel creation by family.
4. Robustness via exclusion of borderline cases using _bl and _nobl fields.
5. Special handling of 1900/2100 is necessary for timeline and panel construction.

versions.label: PopuList 3.0: structure, contents, and research uses
versions.description:
Each row: a political party in Europe, with expert-coded classifications, sometimes for multiple time periods.

Key columns:
- country, party, party abbreviation (partyabbrev), party id (id), and whether in parliament (inparliament)
- party family (partyfam), populist/far-right/far-left/sovereignist/Eurosceptic flags: (pop, frrp, frlp, sov, eu)
- start, end, firstyear: temporal scope of classification (start_end range marks when the party meets given classification)
- _bl or _nobl fields: marks borderline or consensus classifications (for sensitivity)

Example: Rassemblement National (France) - pop=1, frrp=1, inparliament=1, start=2018, end=2022

Research uses:
1. Track populist/far-right/far-left party emergence and duration using start/end columns.
2. Merge with COVID/policy datasets (e.g. OxCGRT) to compare responses or narratives under populist vs. non-populist governments.
3. Group by party type (far-right/far-left/sovereignist) for comparative study of party evolution, electoral success, or ideological responses.
4. Filter on borderline flags to restrict analysis to high-certainty classifications or perform robustness checks.

newNodes.label: PopuList 3.0: placeholder year codes 1900 and 2100
newNodes.description: The PopuList 3.0 dataset uses 1900 and 2100 as special codes in columns such as populist_start, populist_end, farright_start, etc., instead of literal years. According to the codebook, 1900 marks the first year available for coding (usually 1989/start of party history), and 2100 means the populist/far-right/etc. status continued until the final year in the dataset (e.g., as of 2022). This encoding design simplifies filtering, plotting, and timeline merges. For meaningful time-series comparison, analysts should remap these codes to actual years.

summary: Data node for PopuList 3.0 updated, now explicitly describing special year codes 1900 and 2100 used as placeholders for start/end of party classifications, plus guidance on timeline handling. Added an Explanation node on the semantics of 1900/2100 and linked this to the dataset node.

newNodes.label: Austria-specific extraction and output preparation from PopuList 3.0
newNodes.description:
Step 1: Discover and resolve CSV loading error (semicolon delimiter issue).
Step 2: Reload PopuList 3.0 using corrected delimiter.
Step 3: Extract all parties where country_name == 'Austria' into a separate table.
Step 4: Prepare Austria-specific party subset as downloadable CSV.
Step 5: Prepare timeline visualization (1989–2022) for populist party classification in Austria, showing periods when each Austrian party was classified as populist (X-axis: years; Y-axis: party names; indicator: classification period).
Step 6: Provide visual as downloadable/chart object.

newNodes.label: Timeline visualization: Austrian party existence by ideology, 1989–2022 (lifespan, color-coded by type)
newNodes.description: A revised graphical timeline displaying Austrian political parties (Y-axis) and the years (X-axis, 1989–2022) that each party existed (from foundation to dissolution), with color encoding for ideology. Each bar segment reflects the actual party lifespan (from party_founded to party_dissolved/2022). Color legend: Red for Far-right, Blue for Far-left, Orange for Populist (not classified as far-right or far-left), Gray for Other or Unclassified. The timeline does not show populist classification periods, only the time of party existence as determined from augmented data. Uses updated Austria dataset with new party_founded/party_dissolved columns, and classification columns for ideology label.

newNodes.label: Austria party subset: PopuList 3.0 CSV extract with party foundation/dissolution dates
newNodes.description: Table/CSV containing all rows from PopuList 3.0 where country_name equals Austria, now with two added columns: party_founded (year party was founded) and party_dissolved (year party was dissolved, if applicable). This enhances the dataset, allowing for analyses incorporating both the time window of populist classification and the actual lifespan of each party. Derived directly from the cleaned input dataset and external historical sources.

summary: A new Task node details Austria-specific extraction/cleaning and outputs from PopuList 3.0, with steps for delimiter correction, extraction, and prep of both CSV and timeline visualization. Added Data node for the Austria-only party subset and a Visualization node for the timeline of Austrian populist parties (1989–2022), together with links connecting the overall workflow.

updatedNodes.label: Timeline visualization: Austrian populist party classifications (1989–2022) [default color, not real lifespan/classification tracking]
updatedNodes.description: A graphical timeline plot displaying Austrian political parties (Y-axis) and the years (X-axis, 1989–2022) each is classified as populist, based on PopuList 3.0. Each bar/segment indicates the period of populist status per party. Current version: Colors are arbitrary (automatically assigned by matplotlib, with no substantive encoding). Does not yet distinguish party ideologies, borderline cases, or classification changes. Plot periods correspond to intervals where parties receive a nonzero populist classification (per populist_start and populist_end fields) — not actual party lifespans.

newNodes.label: Timeline visualization: arbitrary colors, limitations, and interpretation rules
newNodes.description:
• The colors in the visual as currently generated reflect only the default order given by matplotlib, with no inherent meaning (i.e., not by ideology or status).
• Visual does not encode ideologies, borderline status, or changes in party classification over time.
• Timeline windows (colored bars) for each party reflect only the period during which experts labeled the party as 'populist' in PopuList 3.0 (using populist_start and populist_end codebook encodings, including placeholder years 1900/2100 ➔ interpreted as 1989/2022).
• The plot does not show party formation/founding or dissolution: the data encodes only the span of the populist label, not the true existence/lifespan of the party.
• Some parties (e.g. BZÖ [founded 2005], Team Stronach [active ~2012–17]) have populist periods in the dataset inconsistent with full party lifespans.
• Accurate interpretation requires external data for true party founding/dissolution; misleading to treat these windows as party existence.

Added a detailed Explanation node covering visual semantics, codebook logic (use of 1900/2100), and analysis limitations, linking this to prior nodes for visualization, PopuList data logic, and code conventions.

newNodes.label: Suggested analytic uses for PopuList 3.0 dataset
newNodes.description:
Core Use Cases:
1. Track rise and spread of populism over time using populist_start and populist_end fields; compare populism waves across countries/periods.
2. Analyze populism's relationship to government power (identify populists in parliament, examine government/populist policy responses).
3. Compare populist ideologies: far-right, far-left, centrist (analyze Euroscepticism, nativism, authoritarianism, climate/pandemic policies).
4. Merge PopuList party/periods with other datasets using IDs or country/party fields (e.g. OxCGRT, election results, trust surveys, economic outcomes).

Suggested visualizations:
- Timelines by country showing populist party periods
- Europe-wide populist party presence maps
- Stacked area: populism growth over time
- Scatter plots: populism vs COVID/EU trust

Technical: Use built-in IDs for data linkage, track ideology changes by party/year.

summary: A new Suggestion node summarizes analytic strategies for using the PopuList 3.0 dataset, referencing core use cases, recommended visualizations, and integration with other datasets. This provides a high-level guide for leveraging PopuList as an analytical foundation for comparative politics and pandemic-era research.

newNodes.label: Austria: No parties became populist after 1989 in PopuList 3.0
newNodes.description: According to the Austria-specific PopuList 3.0 extract, all parties flagged as populist have populist_start = 1900 (i.e., 1989), meaning none are recorded as having adopted populism after 1989. Either these parties were already seen as populist at the beginning of the classification period, or the dataset lacks entries for parties that acquired populist status later.

newNodes.label: Suggested cross-country search for parties with populist_start after 1989
newNodes.description:
Expand search beyond Austria. Query the full PopuList 3.0 dataset for cases where:
- populist == 1,
- populist_start > 1989.
Retrieve parties from across all countries that were not classified as populist at the start of the classification window but became so during 1990–2022.

summary: A new Finding highlights that in the Austria-specific PopuList extract, no parties are marked as becoming populist after 1989. A Suggestion recommends extending the search to the entire dataset to identify such cases for other countries, proposing a filter on populist_start > 1989. These nodes clarify temporal classification limitations and next analytic steps on cross-national trajectories.

newNodes.label: Parties that became populist after 1989: PopuList 3.0 examples
newNodes.description: In the full PopuList 3.0 dataset, there are multiple real examples of parties that became populist after 1989 (i.e., their populist_start is after the start of the coding window). These parties were not classified as populist at the beginning of the observation period, but attained this classification in later years according to PopuList coding.

newNodes.label: Suggested next steps: Populist transition parties analysis
newNodes.description:
Potential next steps for the analyst based on the newly identified group of parties that became populist after 1989:
- Export the full list of such parties to CSV for further analysis.
- Generate a timeline visualization of their transition to populism.
- Compare each party's policy behaviors (PopuList fields or joinable outcomes) before and after their populist classification date.
System awaits analyst choice for next exploration step.

summary: A new Finding confirms the existence of parties that became populist after 1989 in the full PopuList 3.0 dataset. The system adds a Suggestion outlining next analytic steps—export as CSV, timeline visualization, or before/after policy comparison—linked to this group of parties and inviting the analyst to choose a focus.

newNodes.label: Whole-dataset addition of party_founded and party_dissolved columns
newNodes.description:
For each party in the full PopuList 3.0 dataset, add the party_founded and party_dissolved columns by:
- Automated lookup via Wikidata (API/SPARQL queries), PartyFacts, or ParlGov (where IDs exist).
- Name-matching logic for party_name_english/short, with handling for non-unique or inconsistent names.
- Supplement with manual curation/scraping for obscure/short-lived parties or failed matches.
- Allow for partial completion (fill for major parties, highlight NaN for unresolved cases).
Estimates: Automated fill (top 100+ parties) takes 10–30 minutes to run; manual/cleanup may require several hours. Analyst may choose between full automation, subset focus, or quality threshold for fill.

newNodes.label: Automated party foundation/dissolution year fill strategy options
newNodes.description:
Options for populating party_founded and party_dissolved columns for all parties:
- Use automated Wikidata/PartyFacts queries for bulk fill (fast, possible gaps).
- Restrict to main parties (e.g., those in parliament) for higher confidence and faster delivery.
- Accept partial/approximate matches and NaN for unresolved names.
- System offers to prepare auto-fill script and summary of rows requiring manual review.
Awaiting analyst's choice on detail level preferred.

summary: Task node added for the whole-dataset enrichment of PopuList with party_founded and party_dissolved columns, outlining sources/methodology and estimated auto/manual effort. A Suggestion explicates implementation options, such as automated vs. subset restriction and partial fill, with next action depending on analyst preferences. Both nodes link to the core PopuList dataset.

newNodes.label: Graph: Number of active populist parties in Europe, 1989–2022
newNodes.description: A line graph plotting the evolution of the number of active populist parties per year across Europe using PopuList 3.0 data. The X-axis covers years 1989–2022. The Y-axis shows the number of parties classified as populist in each year, based on populist_start and populist_end coding for each party. The plot reveals a steady rise throughout the 1990s and 2000s, acceleration in the 2010s, and a plateau in the 2020s (possibly due to party consolidation or reclassification). Image link and downloadable chart provided by the system.

newNodes.label: Populist party trend interpretation: Europe-wide (1989–2022)
newNodes.description: The total number of active populist parties in Europe steadily increases from the 1990s into the 2010s, with sharp growth in the 2000s and 2010s. After 2020, the count stabilizes or slightly declines, which may reflect party consolidation or coding/reclassification rather than an actual reversal. Suggests the populist party presence now remains high but has stopped expanding rapidly.

newNodes.label: Suggested breakdowns for populist evolution graph
newNodes.description:
Options for further disaggregating the overall populist party evolution:
- By region: Western vs. Eastern Europe
- By ideology: far-right vs. far-left
- By status: parties in parliament only
System awaits analyst direction for deeper group-level analysis or specific breakdown choice.

summary: Visualization node added for a line graph showing Europe-wide growth and plateau in the number of populist parties (1989–2022) based on PopuList 3.0; linked to its data source. Insight interprets the pattern as a steady rise with post-2020 stabilization. Suggestion offers further group-level breakdowns (region, ideology, parliamentary status).

newNodes.label: Graph: Active populist parties in Western vs Eastern Europe (1989–2022)
newNodes.description: A dual-line graph comparing the count of active populist parties per year for Western and Eastern Europe, based on PopuList 3.0. X-axis: years 1989–2022. Y-axis: number of populist parties in each region (calculated annually according to populist_start and populist_end codes). Western Europe shows a steady, gradual climb with sudden acceleration in the 2010s; Eastern Europe shows a sharp jump in the late 1990s, rapid increase in the 2000s, and relative stability thereafter. Provided as an image and downloadable file.

newNodes.label: Regional populist evolution patterns: Western vs Eastern Europe
newNodes.description:
Eastern Europe: Rapid surge in populist parties post-1990, peaking as post-communist fragmentation and new party formation surge occurred.
Western Europe: Slower but persistent increase, major acceleration in the 2010s, plausibly linked to migration crisis, austerity, and Eurosceptic politics.
Both regions now exhibit high but plateaued numbers of populist parties, via different historical processes.

newNodes.label: Further subgroup breakdown suggestions for party evolution graphs
newNodes.description:
Additional suggested granularity:
- By country: individual timelines for specific European states
- By parliamentary presence: restrict to parties with in_parliament == 1
- By ideology: break down into far-right vs far-left populists
System awaits analyst direction for next focus.

summary: Visualization node created for a Western vs Eastern Europe comparison of active populist parties (1989–2022), disaggregating the Europe-wide trend. Insight interprets divergent regional trajectories—Eastern Europe saw a post-1990 surge, Western Europe a more recent rise. System offers a new Suggestion for further breakdowns (country, in-parliament, ideology).

newNodes.label: Population time series: Western and Eastern Europe by region/year
newNodes.description: Time series vectors: Total population for Western Europe and Eastern Europe, in millions, for each year 1989–2022. Sources include World Bank and Eurostat as referenced in calculation. Aggregated annually: sum of country populations for each region (regions as defined in the 'Country lists' node). Underlies normalization of party counts to "parties per 10 million people".

newNodes.label: Normalized graph: Populist parties per 10 million people, Western vs Eastern Europe (1989–2022)
newNodes.description: Line chart: Y-axis is 'Number of active populist parties per 10 million population'; X-axis is years 1989–2022; separate lines for Western and Eastern Europe. Computed by dividing annual active populist party counts (from PopuList 3.0) by total region population (see separate node), multiplying by 10^7. Demonstrates higher per-capita party rates in Eastern Europe regardless of total country count.

newNodes.label: Key finding: Per-capita populist party prevalence, regional comparison
newNodes.description: Eastern Europe has a consistently higher number of active populist parties per 10 million people throughout 1989–2022 (normalized for population). updatedNodes.label: V-Dem v15: full structure and main variable domains
updatedNodes.description:
V-Dem (Varieties of Democracy) dataset structure and content as per codebook and system summary:

1. Core Indices (composite, continuous 0–1, country-year):
   - Liberal Democracy Index (LDI)
   - Electoral Democracy Index (EDI)
   - Participatory Democracy Index
   - Deliberative Democracy Index
   - Egalitarian Democracy Index

2. Elections & Electoral Integrity:
   - Free/fair election ratings (v2elefree, v2eltype_*)
   - Election violence, democracy types (autocracy/democracy)

3. Rule of Law & Judiciary:
   - Judicial independence (v2jureview, v2jupurge)
   - Access to justice, executive/judicial interaction

4. Freedom of Expression & Media:
   - Freedom of speech/media/academic (v2mefreedom, internet filtering etc.)

5. Civil Society & Participation:
   - Levels of civil society activism/repression
   - Rights to association/assembly
   - Government engagement with CSOs

6. Equality & Inclusion:
   - Equal protection under the law
   - Distribution of power—gender, class, ethnicity
   - Discrimination measures

7. Executive Constraints & Corruption:
   - Legislative/judicial/media checks on the executive
   - Executive corruption, transparency, accountability (v2excrptps)

8. Autocracy & Repression:
   - Measures of autocracy, regime type, purges
   - Political harassment, civil liberties violations

9. Political Parties:
   - Party bans/repression
   - Opposition autonomy
   - Party-society linkages

10. Miscellaneous/Other:
   - Regime duration/transitions, constitutional/military/religious role

Coverage: ~450 indicators, annotated by label. Annual, country-level, 1900–present. Full variable list can be extracted if needed. COVID-19 special section noted in dataset (not detailed here but present).

summary: data_8 (V-Dem structure) updated: now a comprehensive overview of the main measurement domains and indicator types available in V-Dem v15, organized hierarchically per the codebook. Variable themes, example codes, coverage notes, and the scale of indicator counts are included.

newNodes.label: Romania V-Dem indices: explanation of sharp 1940 drop and 1989–2000 rise
newNodes.description:
Interpretation of major discontinuities in Romania's V-Dem democracy indices based on historical events:

1. Sharp drop ~1940:
   - 1938: King Carol II institutes royal dictatorship, suspending constitution
   - 1940: Abdication, Iron Guard/fascist-military regime, WWII/Nazi alignment
   - Effects: End of elections, suppression of pluralism, authoritarian/fascist governance (reflected as index collapse)

2. Sharp rise 1989–2000:
   - 1989: Violent Romanian Revolution, collapse of Ceaușescu’s communist regime
   - 1990s: First multi-party elections (1990), new democratic constitution (1991), EU-alignment reforms
   - 2000s: Institutional consolidation, EU accession by 2007
   - Effects: Restoration of elections, judicial/media reform, civic and political freedoms (reflected as index rebound)

Full temporal context: Indices track regime breakdown (authoritarian/WWII/fascist collapse), communist persistence, then rapid post-communist democratization.

summary: Added insight_7 node interpreting the key temporal breaks in Romania's democracy indices—explaining the sharp drop around 1940 and steep rise around 1989–2000 as responses to dictatorship, WWII/fascism, and post-communist transition. This insight is now linked to both the Romania line plot (visualization_6) and the underlying V-Dem subset (data_13).

newNodes.label: Why Electoral Democracy Index (Romania) not much lower under communism: mid-level component breakdown
newNodes.description:
Breakdown of the V-Dem Electoral Democracy Index (v2x_polyarchy) to resolve why Romanian scores during communism (1960–1989) do not drastically underperform the interwar years:

Mid-level components include:
- v2elmulpar (Multiparty elections): Were multiple parties allowed to contest?
- v2elfrfair (Free and fair elections): Was the process competitive/impartial?
- v2elvotbuy (Vote buying): Was clientelism or bribery present?
- v2elirreg (Election irregularities): Were there procedural flaws?
- v2x_suffr (Suffrage): Was the right to vote broadly inclusive?

Context:
- Communist era: Universal suffrage and regular elections, but with no genuine competition (single-party, state repression)
- Interwar era: Some pluralism, but electoral violence, manipulation, and increasing authoritarianism in the late 1930s

Summary: Due to universal suffrage and regular voting, some components retain moderate scores under communism even as competition/fairness indicators collapse. This explains the index not falling extremely low in communist period.

Next-step suggestion: Extract and plot these mid-level variables to compare interwar, communist, and post-1990 democratic periods.

newNodes.label: Extract and plot V-Dem mid-level electoral indicators (Romania, by regime period)
newNodes.description:

   * v2elfrfair (fair/competitive)
   * v2elvotbuy (vote buying)
   * v2elirreg (irregularities)
   * v2x_suffr (suffrage)
- Segment by regime period: interwar (1919–1939), communist (1947–1989), democratic (post-1990)
- Plot these series for visual comparison, highlighting which components explain period differences or similarities in the top-level Electoral Democracy Index.
Result: Reveals dimension-level explanations for the main index's historical patterns.

newNodes.label: Explanation: 2019–2022 spikes in Romanian democracy indices
newNodes.description:
Explains the unusual dip, sharp rise, and subsequent drop in Romania’s V-Dem democracy indices circa 2019–2022:

Timeline of Political Events:
2017–2019: Mass protests over anti-corruption law changes; ruling PSD pushes controversial judicial reforms (EU warnings, V-Dem concern)
Mid-2019: PSD government falls; President Iohannis’s liberals strengthen; reform momentum/judiciary independence spike (likely explains brief rise)
2020–2021: Political instability returns; COVID-19, anti-vaccine populism, attacks on press/judiciary (explains drop again in 2021–2022)

Pattern interpretaton:
- Dip reflects PSD backsliding, attacks on checks and balances
- Sharp rise: reform push under new leadership
- Renewed drop: polarization and diminished reform amid pandemic/instability
Indices track these regime events, causing the abnormal fluctuations.

newNodes.label: Drilldown: Identify sub-indices shifting during 2019–2022 in Romania
newNodes.description:
Offer to further investigate V-Dem sub-indices for Romania to pinpoint the mechanics of 2019–2022 democracy index spikes by:
- Extracting indicators such as judicial independence, executive corruption, deliberative democracy
- Visualizing or quantifying which sub-indices explain the rapid upswings and downswings
- Focusing on 2019–2022 period
Purpose: To attribute index volatility to institutional or political mechanisms in those years.

summary: insight_8 was added, interpreting the 2019–2022 spikes in Romania's democracy indices as reflections of regime change, reform, and renewed instability, citing concrete political events. suggestion_20 invites the next drilling step: pinpointing which V-Dem sub-indices (e.g. judicial independence, executive corruption) explain the spike. visualization_6 was updated to focus on the 2000–2022 segment per the analyst's timeframe re-focus.

newNodes.label: Are V-Dem scores for Romania influenced by recency effects or better information in recent years?
newNodes.description: To what extent are the V-Dem democracy index scores for Romania shaped by real changes in democratic quality versus changes in data visibility, media coverage, and information availability in more recent decades? Specifically, do events of similar severity (e.g., the 1990s miners' revolts) display smaller index effects in earlier periods due to less coverage or observer access?

newNodes.label: Factors affecting V-Dem time-series comparability: recency, information, method changes
newNodes.description:
Three main sources for possible recency bias or informational asymmetry in V-Dem:
1. Recency effects: Post-2010 events are better documented due to more sources, civil society, and international monitoring.
2. Event severity vs data coverage: Major earlier events (e.g., 1990/91 Mineriads) may be under-registered as there were fewer watchdogs and less access for coders.
3. Methodology changes: Over time, V-Dem adds indicators, rotates coders, and slightly shifts framing, potentially creating measurement noise—especially in the early 2000s or before.

newNodes.label: Methods to assess or mitigate recency and measurement bias in V-Dem for Romania
newNodes.description:
Analytical suggestions to address recency bias and informational asymmetry in V-Dem:
- Annotate timeline visualizations of Romanian democracy with major shocks/events and observe their V-Dem responses across decades
- Apply a 'visibility adjustment lens' (e.g., rate media/observer coverage for major incidents by decade)
- Examine coder disagreement/uncertainty bounds over time (V-Dem provides these), especially for older years
- Track changes in V-Dem's indicators, coder pool, and question phrasing as possible noise factors
- Consider cross-validating V-Dem data with alternative indices for older periods

summary: research_question_3 was added, focusing on whether Romanian V-Dem scores reflect real change or measurement/visibility/recency effects. explanation_6 details three main bias sources in V-Dem data: recency, event coverage limitations, and evolving methodology. suggestion_21 presents concrete analytic strategies to interrogate/mitigate these biases, such as annotating events, visibility adjustment, and checking coder agreement over time. Key links tie these nodes to recent index-spike insights and the underlying Romania time-series visualization.

newNodes.label: Limitation: Official democracy data capture and election timing
newNodes.description: The available data on democracy quality and changes primarily records "official" degradations triggered by measures introduced by newly elected administrations. This introduces a blind spot for lagged effects of social/political shocks (e.g., COVID-driven voting shifts) that only affect democracy scores after subsequent elections, as illustrated by the US case (Trump elected post-COVID, data not yet reflecting expected democracy declines attributable to pandemic-driven voting changes).

Lines: each of the five V-Dem indices; election year marked by dashed line. Downloadable image provided.

newNodes.label: Further analytical drilldowns: pre/post-election democracy trends
newNodes.description:
The system offers these next steps:
- Produce country-specific panels (small multiples) for pre/post-election democracy changes
- Show change distributions (gains/losses) as histograms
- Disaggregate by election year: 2022 vs. 2023
- Analyst can request deeper dives along any of these axes

summary: The workflow advanced with the actual delivery of the filtered dataset (updated task_8), fulfilling the pending file extraction. A new visualization_11 node captures the released average-level democracy index plot, summarizing indicator trends pre/post-election across the 15 countries. The visualization_10 node was updated for clarity, and system-proposed suggestion_25 now explicitly enumerates next-level analytical drilldown options. Links clarify these operational progressions.
